title: Before 1 January 2018, will Fitch, Moody's, or S&P cut the State of Illinois’ credit rating to junk status?
preds: Monitoring current political adherence to liberal stands for spending vs saving in II
There isn't enough financial news pending for them to make that decision before year's end.  An unemployment jump may do it, but that would have a significant lead time.

Reaffirming my forecast, but considering new information. A new article from Pensions & Investments (http://www.pionline.com/article/20171207/ONLINE/171209871/moodys-proposes-upping-pension-debt-weighting-in-credit-rating-decisions), with the headline “Moody’s proposes upping pension debt weighting in credit-rating decisions”, implies Moody’s is preparing to give Illinois a junk bond rating.  Moody’s is calling for comments from market participants.  Given the timing, the probability is low that a final decision will happen until this question has expired.

Probably not this year, but there is a downgrade in the future: http://www.tribuneledgernews.com/extra/news/in-spite-of-tax-hike-ratings-agency-eyes-change-that/article_bf6fce83-a9d8-5e94-9079-00924711f2b9.html
near as I can tell from alerts ive set, Moodys is yraveling to various state capitals with forwcasts of doom due to revenue shortfalls whereever leguslatirs are in a mood to cut.

Hilarious: Chicago is issuing "AAA"-rated debt. I'm raising forecast slightly just because of how absurd this is; the ratings agencies might feel suddenly sheepish, but I'm not holding my breath. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-05/chicago-tests-bond-market-alchemy-with-debut-of-aaa-rated-debt
description embedded in the link is a better read than the headline ("chicago tests bond market alchemy with debut of aaa rated debt")

Reaffirming my forecast for the following reasons: First, the bad news for Illinois.  The pension funding ratio is at 38% because unfunded liabilities have grown to $130B.  Next, the unpaid vendor backlog is at $16B.  You can handwave unfunded liabilities since they do not come due all at once, but it’s still a long-term problem.  The vendors appear that they won’t precipitate a crisis right before Christmas.  And even if they did, would the agencies react?  I don’t believe they would do any such thing right before Christmas. Now the good news for Illinois.  Chicago has just issued AAA-rated bonds through Goldman Sachs.  The story is in the Wall Street Journal (https://www.wsj.com/articles/how-cash-strapped-chicago-snagged-a-triple-a-rating-for-its-new-bonds-1512320401).  (It’s behind a paywall, but I assume everybody knows the trick to getting around that.) How was this accomplish?  The new bonds are have a dedicated first claim to city sales-tax revenue.  Wait a minute, I hear you say, how can they subordinate all the other bond holder claims?  Well, it appears they just have to say so.  (This is the famous “We can do it, so shut your cakehole” gambit.) My process says to never rate a forecast at 0% unless it is a physical impossibility.  It is possible that Illinois will get a rating downgrade from the credit agencies.  The probability, in my opinion, is very low.

Passage of time
Additional info is that Illinois' bicentennial is coming up. Some expectation of a stimulated economy will help with stability.

1 - Moody's first assign BBB3 to State of Illinois on 7/1/2017, Given 5 out of 6 months passed but rating hasn't changed. 
My 3rd try would be: 48%(first try)*1/6=8% 
2 - Holiday season: unlikely to announce big negative change on the state credit, so drop it to 2%.

If it was going to be done, my sense is that it would’ve been done sooner. The actions of the legislature as noted in the Chicago Tribune article I think forestalled such a move, at least until the next budget battle.
Cut? Yeah maybe, it's Illinois! To Junk?! Nah!
They have not dowgraded Venezuela yet they should do it to Illions?! Dont think so.

The three agencies have all been consistently downgrading Illinois's credit rating, and the question only requires one of them to cut the credit rating down again in the next two months. The passage of the budget in July makes it unlikely the credit rating will be downgraded further however. The 3 different agencies know that downgrading Illinois so far would set an extraordinary precedent. At the beginning of the next year though, expect a re-investigation into this question due to the unresolved pension problem. Governor election incoming as well. This is all thinking past Jan 1 of course, outside the scope of the question.
Illinois is a basket case, but has kicked the can down the road for now.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Moody's first assign BBB3 to State of Illinois on 7/1/2017, Given 4 out of 6 months passed but rating hasn't changed. 
My 2nd try is: 48%(first try)*2/6=16%

Thanks to @REBurnerAccount for sharing the Fitch and S&P commentary after the recent Illinois bond sale. The bond sale (and another one later this week) should take some pressure off Illinois by lowering interest costs on the state's backlog of unpaid bills. http://www.kwqc.com/content/news/State-of-Illinois-sells-15-billion-in-bonds-451330133.html With a little over two months to go, I'm hanging on to the 1% safety margin "just in case" a Black Swan event wreaks havoc with my understanding of this question (Brier score asymmetries at work here - not much to gain from dropping down to 0% and a lot of pain if that doggone Black Swan comes in under the radar!).

Maintain at 0%.  Fitch just signaled that they would not move the credit rating unless there was further deterioration at the government level in the near term (also warning the government that they need to get their act together). "Eric Kim, Fitch's head of U.S. Public Finance, said the credit rating ought to be higher and that’s despite Illinois' massive debt and pension liabilities." S&P made similar statements after rating the recent bond sale: Illinois on Monday maintained a BBB-minus rating and stable outlook from S&P Global Ratings...S&P said while the new budget eased concerns over a liquidity crisis for the state and reduced the odds for a rating downgrade, it includes some “doubtful” savings and nonrecurring revenue.
A report released Monday says  although Illinois has the lowest credit rating in the country, the state also has a “robust economic base.”
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

1st forecast: Currently it is one level away from junk. I think the probability range for the junk ranking happing before 1/1/2018 is 10%-90%, the middle rate is 50%. Given the BBB- rating hasn't changed for  almost three months since it is first being issued, the rate change in the next 70 days will be relatively unlikely. so drop the probability to 48%

Hard to see this happening before 1 January 2018. While it is true that the state remains at risk of having its credit downgraded despite passing a budget, Fitch reaffirmed a rating that is two notches above junk (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-illinois-ratings-fitch/illinois-credit-rating-stays-investment-grade-with-fitch-idUSKBN1A22C0) and both S&P and Moody's applauded the budget decision. If this downgrade happens, it will be in 2018 or 2019. The long-term issues haven't gone away, but I see little basis for the ratings agencies to take such harsh action in the remainder of 2017. If the budget decision weren't enough to stave off the downgrade, they wouldn't have reaffirmed their investment-grade ratings.
Pressure on credit rating agencies to not downgrade a government entity, coupled with the recently passed budget by the Illinois state legislature, will allow the state to avoid a downgrade.

Reasons for low probability: 1. The state recently passed a budget, permanently raising tax rates which should raise revenue by around 5 or 6 billion a year. 2. All three credit agencies applauded the passing of the budget. 3. With the budget passed, the state was able to issue bonds and pay down some of its accruing obligations. The bonds have a much lower interest rate (3.5% vs 12+%) than the accrued obligations.  4. With the approved increase in tax rates and lower bond interest rates, the state budget outlook has improved from earlier in the year when all three rating agencies put the state on watch. While the state's budget is still not entirely stable, it seems highly unlikely it will worsen enough over the next two plus months to warrant a downgrade.  5. From an outside perspective, no state has ever received a junk rating. The rating agencies would need to make a substantial argument to make Illinois the first. They might have that argument sometime in 2018 or 2019 if finances deteriorate, but it seems unlikely they will have it before the end of the year.

Reaffirming my forecast for the following reasons: 1) The question is asking what the ratings agencies will do, and not what I might think should happen. I don’t believe the ratings agencies are motivated by financial considerations only or I would forecast differently. 2) There has been no news since July.  Maybe nobody is looking.  Maybe nobody cares.  However, the citizens of Illinois are not being prepared for what might be coming either.  No public pressure is being placed on politicians to divert the mess.  Two dogs that haven’t barked. 3) Whether it is ratings agencies or equity analysts, they tend to be late.  The classic example is the Enron failure.  There were recommendations to buy all the way to about 90% down from the high.  The ratings agencies will cut Illinois a break long past what anyone would believe is reasonable.  A counter-argument is we may have reached that point. 4) I know a banker who explained bank failures to me.  The heads of bank on the verge of failure know how desperate their situation is, but for the most part the employees or customers do not.  FDIC waits until they have everything ready: the examiners, large amounts of cash, and the plan for other local banks to come into the picture as backstops.  On a Friday afternoon, at closing time, the bank is shut down.  The examiners work through the weekend, and the bank usually can open early the next week.  Disruption in minimized.  Given the situation in Puerto Rico, the entire US Government is not prepared for the implications of a downgrade to Illinois’ credit.  Nothing will happen until they are ready.  And yes, I believe the ratings agencies pay very careful attention to the desires of the government.  While a credit downgrade is not the same as bankruptcy, in this case it will hit Illinois hard because of additional loan costs.  I see no evidence of such preparation. 5) What is the evidence against my position? 5A) Illinois is overdue in bills to the tune of about $6.7B.  Their creditors would obviously like to get 100% on the dollar.  If some creditor becomes first mover and demands payment, there could be a preference cascade that would force a downgrade or worse. 5B) Elections will be held in 2018.  The governor is up for reelection.  The present governor was elected by “down-state” voters and has been at odds with the state legislature (both parties) and Chicago officials.  Politics may force a credit downgrade by the ratings agencies, if there is no cooperation between the branches of Illinois government.
At moment I've no idea about.
it is not very far to 1 January but October is a dangerous time in financial markets.

Previously unknowledgeable of the situation, but a quick glance suggests it's unlikely because 1. It's never happened to a state
2. There's a short amount of time for it to happen, with a budget near the end of the period (could affect a decision)
No state has ever been downgraded to junk bond status yet. State Gov has usually made a concession at the last minute to avoid junk bond status.

The State's recent bond sale will help pay some of the $16B in outstanding bills.  The unfunded pension liability remains a huge concern.  It is doubtful that Moody's, Fitch, or S&P would downgrade the state's credit rating further hampering any chances of cleaning up their debt.

For a BBB- rated Local Currency state of the union, it is probable that the state of Illinois will remain at the current rating , with a sligh chance to be upgraded one notch or downgraded to Junk status.  Historical default rates based on the frequency of defaults for homogounous cohorts are avilable from the major credit rating agency S&P, Moody's and Fitch.

No state has been given junk status before. This will be the first, the ratings agencies will give its first credit rating of junk with caution. While i think it is inevitable that they will get junk status i think they will be given a chance to enact their budget. If the budget does not yield positive results they then will get the junk status rating, but not before Jan 2018.

S&P  maintains  a BBB-minus rating and stable outlook for the state’s upcoming $6 billion bond sale.  The new budget eased concerns over a liquidity crisis, but Illinois still faces fiscal challenges that could push the rating into junk.

Records from S&P, Moody's and Fitch dating back about half a century show that no states were rated junk. https://www.cnbc.com/2017/06/01/reuters-america-sp-cuts-illinois-credit-rating-to-one-notch-above-junk.html

There is a chance, but very minimal, that junk status will be imposed. The reason that this is unlikely to occur is due to the progression that would ensue. Bottom line is that too much money would be lost from attached markets.

State making progress to find a solution for the problem. Several Republicans turn their back on the Gov., showing that they see the importance to save the state from 'Junk'. Despite that the credit-rating agencies won't rush a downgrading after the State started to show some progress.

Philly fed leading index just turned negative, and the state is one of few without rainy day fund.  On the other hand, Chicago is restructuring a good deal of its debt, ratings agency downgrades tend to lag bad economic news, and national economic backdrop should be stable.

I approached this problem by starting with a base probability determined by past similar situations.  Given that no state has received junk rating in the past 10 years (https://ballotpedia.org/State_credit_ratings), I would put this initial probability at 3 - 4 %, rated as highly unlikely to occur except in extraordinary circumstances.  In the case of Illinois, however, we see a trend of consistent downward ratings.  This is exacerbated by the fact that there are 3 rating agencies that each could independently decide to downgrade the state.  These combined factors might bring my 3 -4 percent up to 20 or 25 percent. That said, the recent passing of a budget by the Illinois legislature and my sense that credit agencies are likely to cling to signs of progress before inflicting the known economic costs of a downgrade on Illinois, I will drop this significantly.  It would then, in my mind hover somewhere between the 20 - 25 and the 3 - 4 percent, putting me at 13%.
Recent passage of temporary budget relief

This is my first forecast and as an European I have no knowledge of Illinios' finances. However the top forecasters seem to be fairly confident that it is a realistic option while other are often less confident. So I will guess somewhat below the top forecasters estimates.

Republicans in the legislator have reached a tipping point. They have already taken the political damage and will continue to support tax legislation through the end of their session. A veto-proof majority is sufficient to stop the vendor payment problems, along with debt servicing. However, the structural problems in Illinois politics may have these agencies consider continuing their downgrade, keeping long term in the view. Finally, the irrational line from non-junk to junk requires greater rational lifting on the credit-agency part. Without a clear indicator to justify downgrade, status quo is likely.

If Illinois credit rating drops to junk, this will completely disrupt the municipal bond market.  It appears this has been a wake up call to the Illinois legislature to take steps to avoid junk status.  Junk status may occur, but not likely by the end of 2017.  http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/politics/ct-bruce-rauner-illinois-credit-rating-met-0713-20170712-story.html
it seems unlikely given Moody's just recently downgraded them, and Moody's is the most likely of the 3.  S&P has their rating outlook as stable and Fitch has them two notches above junk

Credit ratings seem to change for flaky states about once every ~4 years, there's about a third of a year left, so base rate of 8% of the credit rating changing, and 4% of it going down. It seems to have avoided dire straits recently, but it doesn't look like it's doing very well, just not as horrible as it could have been, so probably still around 4%, maybe 5% since it seems a little flakier than usual.
Their rating is already crap, they are overextended in their defined benefits, China is trying to take over the board and Chicago will ultimately implode with its corruption and malfeasance

With less than three months remaining in the year and the recent move to sell bonds to pay down debt, it seems unlikely that the credit rating will be cut by the deadline.  http://www.reuters.com/article/illinois-bonds/update-2-illinois-to-sell-6-75-bln-of-bonds-by-year-end-idUSL2N1M31YM
Trumps policies are increasing Manufacturing production YUGELY so far and the state will benefit tremendously shortly.

Moodys in their report states that the passing of the state budget creates some stability short term. On he other hand Bloomberg's quantitative credit model indicates  a high degree of distress.  This estimate has been falling, and indicates lower credit spreads than what is observed in the market.  Ratings do not change all that often, even with a negative outlook.

back in July 20, Moody says Illinois' rating won't be lowered to "junk" but warns the state still faces serious financial challenges and long-term risks. The state still has the highest unfunded pension liability in US. I suspect the real probability is higher than 60% (c75%) but we only left back 3 months till 1 January, which is why the discount. To note also if Illinois is downgraded it will be the first state in US to have a rating below investment grade.
Levels of crime and employment is a determining factor
Political gridlock remains unresolved in IL.

Illinois, has the lowest credit ratings among the 50 states, and so far it has  evaded downgrades to junk with the budget enactment. But the state's  unpaid bills topped $16 billion for the first time and the Governor Bruce Rauner said that the  sale of  $6 billion of general obligation bonds won't do not solve any problems.  A few days ago Connecticut just had its credit rating downgraded to “deep junk”, just a  few months after the city’s credit rating  was last downgraded.

I broke this assessment into 3 parts, looking at the 3 credit agencies separately. In all 3 cases, Illinois is close to the rating of junk status, and a negative change could push them over the edge. However Illinois has recently passed a budget for 2018 that makes their future outlook more positive. (http://money.cnn.com/2017/07/06/investing/illinois-budget-deal-house-override/index.html).  Looking at each agency, the most recent rating from S&P, affirmed Illinois rating at BBB- with a stable outlook on July 12th. (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-illinois-ratings/illinois-avoids-downgrade-to-junk-as-sp-affirms-bbb-minus-rating-idUSKBN19X2PW). Since that was in July, it is possible that S&P will update this before the end of the year, but due to the stable rating, I judge it unlikely that they will lower this rating until seeing how the 2018 budget is implemented. I give S&P a 10% chance of lowering the rating in the next 2 months. Moody's latest update to Illinois credit rating was also in July, at Baa-3 with a negative outlook. This is potential to update before the end of the year, and with the negative outlook, still possible to have that lowered to junk status. (https://www.moodys.com/research/Moodys-confirms-Illinois-Baa3-GO-and-related-ratings-affecting-32--PR_904132827). However with the recent budget being passed, it is unlikely that this will be lowered unless there is significant issues in setting the budget for 2018. I give this a 20% chance of downgrade.  Fitch's latest rating was also in july giving illinois a BBB with a negative outlook. (https://www.fitchratings.com/site/pr/1026604). Fitch is likely to reasses this rating before year end, and with a negative rating it is possible that it will drop. However, it would have to drop 2 ratings to hit junk status which seems very unlikely, especially considering the budget that was passed by illinois. I give this a 0% chance of reaching junk status by 1/1/2018 To be yes, the rating would have to be downgraded by any of the 3 bureaus. As such, combining the numbers above using the additive probablility rule gives me the 28% likelihood of occurance.

Although Illinois is facing insolvency and has been in such a sad state for a number of years, the passing of a budget (although it is just a "Band-Aid") is forward momentum that has not been seen over the past two years.  Now, if the question were to ask about a longer time horizon, say by the end of 2018 I would associate a greater percentage to this forecast.  Too much turbulence in the political arena in that state right now (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-illinois-budget-idUSKBN19Q2P1) but I don't think this downgrade will occur in the next three months.

Passing of budget and immediate response indicated that risk of an imminent downgrade was reduced. Long-term problems do not appear to have been addressed. Moody's appear most negative (https://www.moodys.com/research/Moodys-confirms-Illinois-Baa3-GO-and-related-ratings-affecting-32--PR_904132827) and suggest that issues such as pension liability could still result in a downgrade in the future, but with just three months until the deadline the chance that this happens in 2017 is still relatively low compared to pre-budget outlook.
This seems more about political gridlock than base rates.

Implied probability of default given by CDS spreads is 5.6 % in 1 year, assuming a recovery rate of 0.75.

WIth the new budget and a plethora of new taxes Illinois should continue to avoid the junk bond rating at least until after the governors election.   It takes time for a one time power house state like Illinois to completely fall apart.  It continues to march in that direction by postponing the painful reality of having promises made which can not be met.  What will be interesting is which of the government responsibilities not met will be the one to finally cause the house of cards to collapse,
Health, education infrastructure or safety?

Illinois narrowly avoided becoming the first U.S. state ever slapped with a "junk" credit rating from S&P Global Ratings after it passed its first budget in more than two years. The ratings firm removed the threat of an imminent downgrade for the fifth most populous state in the country on Wednesday, ruling that the Illinois budget deal has lowered the risk of a "liquidity crisis." Now the state is rated one-notch above "junk" territory, and S&P said the odds of a downgrade within the next year have "substantially diminished." 
http://money.cnn.com/2017/07/12/investing/illinois-budget-crisis-downgrade-sp/ May still get cut to junk, but probably not in the next 6 months.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Recent budget saves the day until next year (only just). With new revenue no risk of missing bond payment due to competing court-mandated payments to other creditors.

As I have previously mentioned, I believe S&P will be the first to announce Illinois in the junk credit rating.  Moody’s just lowered them in June and probably won’t lower them again within 6 months.  Fitch seemingly is not going to lead since it is the smallest credit rating agency. This article seems to be important: http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/politics/ct-bruce-rauner-illinois-credit-rating-met-0713-20170712-story.html The money quote: “S&P Global Ratings cited the bipartisan effort to override Rauner's vetoes last week in announcing it has removed state government from a credit watch with the potential for a downgrade. "We no longer believe the state is at risk of experiencing a liquidity crisis in the near term as it was before," the agency said.” Therefore, I am dropping my forecast based on this news.  Remember, it’s not a question if Illinois deserves or doesn’t deserve such a rating.  We are being asked to predict the actions of the agencies. If Illinois can make it to the beginning of November, they can make it the whole way.

my cynical view says Illinois is so corrupt that I am betting on them doing anything to avoid this, time frame is short and there will be enormous pressure on agencies to avoid this downgrade. But I hope it happens, on a personal level.

The freshly adopted budget isn't fooling anyone, least of all the rating agencies:  It will not do anything to improve the state's financial position, even in the short term.   Nobody wants to be in office around election time when your bonds have become junk--not only do your borrowing costs go up instantly and dramatically, but there is a major sell-off of existing debt by agencies and entities who are not allowed to hold junk as part of a capital requirement; this includes, for example, all the public retirement systems in Illinois and I imagine a fair number of banks.  And while most voters don't bother to understand this, they almost always get the idea that it's pretty embarrassing--and if you're an incumbent, it's at least partly your fault.   Nonetheless, the budget just adopted may be enough of a fig leaf to stave off downgrading for a while yet (and if you've ever tried to stave anything off with a fig leaf, you see the problem).  Ratings agencies are not particularly crooked, but they are not nearly as objective as they want you to believe, and can pretend to be dead when that seems advisable.  My personal guess is that at least until next budget cycle, it would take an actual default on g.o. debt to trigger a downgrade.  However, if the distinguished elected officials of Illinois can't put on a better show of efficacy next year than they have this year or for the past several, things could get Very Bad Indeed; stay tuned.

Since I can't see an obvious way to reply to the comments on my forecast, I'll do it here.  Pardon my ignorance.  Maybe I should try Chrome. To matuschoma: Yeah, good point.  Rating agencies publish "1 Year Transition Probability Matrix" which gives probabilities for transitions from one "rating state" to another.  (If you are familiar with Markov Chains, this is _that_ matrix.)  (See http://media.spglobal.com/documents/SPGlobal_Ratings_Article_13+April+2017_Annual+Corporate+Default+Study+and+Rating+Transitions.pdf, page 56)  The S&P probability of a change in rating in one year from BBB to BB from S&P is 3.2%, and from BBB to B is 0.26%.  The probability of being unchanged in rating in one year is 88%.  Based on poking around, the other agencies have similar figures.  This will skew the distribution toward less than 50% probability. This supports your comment.  However, there is a bit of gamesmanship on my part.  From past experience, I believe the ratings agencies will not downgrade in November or December.  This leaves August, September, October for the bad news to hit.  I don't think Fitch will lead on this rating because it is the smallest of the Big Three, and is more of a follower.  S&P last rated Illinois in September 2016 and I expect them to re-rate this September.  If they don't, I will lower my probabilities in order to recover my Brier score. To Seancarranco: Thanks for the link.  Because Moody's just rated Illinois, I don't think they will re-rate them within the <180 day period left in the question.  They could have downgraded them to junk in June, but decided not to.  I kind of think they are trying to give them extra chances.  S&P is another matter: they rated them one step above junk last year, and I think they will take the lead if Illinois crosses the threshold to junk status.  Again, if it doesn't happen by end of October, it will happen after the question expires (IMO).  In that case, I will lower my score drastically.

Illinois has suffered numerous downgrades from various S&P, Moody's and Fitch since 2009.  The last ratings change from Moody's for Illinois was June 1, 2017.  Currently, S&P, Moody's and Fitch rates Illinois one step above junk status. From this site (https://www.illinoispolicy.org/illinois-on-track-to-become-first-junk-rated-state-in-nation/), we can see a timeline for Illinois’ downgrades starting in 2009.  I’ve reproduced it below, adding Moody’s June 1, 2017 downgrade. Date		Moody’s		S&P		Fitch

Jun ‘17	X This comment box doesn't let me show my distribution, so I'm not showing it.  Just giving my thought process. There are less than 180 days left in this question.  I assume each company has a committee that meets to decide and announce credit rating changes.  It appears there are preferred months for issuing new ratings.  Since Moody’s just downgraded, I do not expect them to immediately downgrade again within the end date of the question.  That leaves S&P and Fitch, and the months of August, September, and October for a new announcement. Because Good Judgment Project has arranged the options in deciles, I will try to come up with a probability distribution also based on deciles.  Once I have this, my prediction will be the median of the distribution. 1. No state in the US has ever had a junk bond rating.  The City of Chicago already has a junk-rating.  The Chicago Public Schools are deep in junk territory.  Illinois Universities are also facing downgrades, but are not at junk levels yet, except for Northeastern Illinois.  But I believe the ratings agencies are not only driven by objective facts but by political realities.  Rating Illinois at that level will be a hardship for the state and so there may be a tendency to give them extra time.  I call these considerations a wash and the distribution is unchanged. 2. Demographics hurts Illinois.  The population of Illinois is going down, therefore the tax-base is shrinking.  Because of tax increases, people who can are leaving the state.  In 2016, Illinois lost more people than any other state.  The state is also divided in terms of political apportionment.  Northern Illinois is dominated by Chicago and is controlled by the Democratic Party.  Southern Illinois is Republican.  The governor is Republican.  The state legislature has raised taxes over the governor’s veto.  I do not expect a credible plan to come from the political leaders of Illinois. 3. Higher interest rates are demanded for Illinois bonds.  The bond traders are already ahead of the rating agencies in this regard.  What the credit rating agencies do may be a moot point.  Spending cuts may not be an option either.  There are court orders and consent decrees that force state spending.  The pension obligations are also written into law.  Based on this, redo the distribution again. The median of this probability distribution is in the 50-60% bin.
